Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick case file just delivered, its weight a silent reminder of my duty as a judge. The hearing was in two weeks, but I knew the expectation: review every detail, no matter how routine the case seemed. My colleagues respected my diligence, and I prided myself on never being unprepared. Yet tonight, the community study circle would gather, and I was expected to recite and reflect on verses from the Quran I hadn’t yet read. The anticipation in the group was high; I was supposed to lead the discussion, to inspire. My mind tugged in two directions—one toward the solemn responsibility of justice, the other toward the spiritual nourishment I craved and the community that looked to me. I stared at the unopened file, then at my Quran, feeling the pressure of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
